results.title: Mad Dog and Glory
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Barbara de Fina, Martin Scorsese and John McNaughton
results.brief_description: Robert De Niro and Uma Thurman star as title characters Mad Dog and Glory in this unassuming romantic comedy. A divorced evidence gathering policeman and aspiring photographer, Wayne “Mad Dog” Dobie earns his nickname in reference to his mild mannered nature. One night while on duty Mad Dog inadvertently saves the life of local gangster and part time comedian Frank Milo (a dour Bill Murray, cast against type). Under guidance from his therapist and eager to bring happiness to the life of someone who empathises with his desire to be someone else, Milo befriends Mad Dog and loans Glory (Thurman) to him for a week. Before the week is over Mad Dog and Glory have fallen in love and the two are faced with settling Glory’s brother’s gambling debt to Milo in exchange for their relationship. Cast also includes David Caruso and Mike Star as convincingly menancing sidekick heavyweights and Kathy Baker as Mad Dog’s neighbour.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Universal Pictures, Barbara de Fina, Martin Scorsese and John McNaughton

results.title: Macrame
results.brief_description: This film gives an introduction to the craft of macrame, showing the basic knots and how they can be used to create chains, twists and spirals to give a variegated effect. The film also introduces the craft.

results.title: Mackintosh 1868-1928
results.creator_credit: International Film Associates, Films of Scotland, Scottish Arts Council and Murray Grigor
results.brief_description: Born in Glasgow in 1868, Charles Rennie Mackintosh was one of the first pioneers of modern design and architecture. Combining Scottish, Japanese and English influences, he created styles and designs which were not just ahead of his time but ones which stand the test of time. His contribution to the world of art and design is now recognised internationally. This documentary traces his career from his early paintings to his architectural commissions and the final landscapes. Mackintosh’s work was a complete reversal of contemporary design, he made decoration intrinsic to the whole.

results.title: Mackenna's gold
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, Carl Foreman, Dimitri Tiomkin and J Thompson
results.brief_description: A dying Indian entrusts sherrif Mackenna (Gregory Peck) with a map of the legendary Valley of Gold. After memorising the contents of the map Mackenna destroys it, thus placing himself in a precarious position of being a target to the local bandit gang as well as the townspeople. The two parties are united by a greed for gold and a fear of the common enemy, the Apaches. The gold in the canyon belongs to the Apaches and it has been decreed by Apache Gods that the gold remain untouched. Both those who are hunting the gold, and the Apaches who are protecting it have their own reasons behind desiring its possession, leading to a violent climax. Cast includes Gregory Peck, Omar Sharif, Telly Savalas, Burgess Meredith and Edward G Robinson. Also included on the tape are original theatrical trailers and behind the scenes information.

results.title: Macintosh Classic
results.brief_description: If you took a computer class in Australia during the early 1990s, chances are you used one of these boxy personal computers. The Macintosh Classic was released in October 1990 and was the first Macintosh computer to sell for less than $1,000 US dollars, making it one of the most affordable computers on the market at the time. It was really just a cheaper version of the Macintosh SE without as many features, which had been released in 1987, and the Macintosh Classic was seen by some as an attempt to squeeze a few more years out of the earlier model. Part of its reduced cost was due to being made in Singapore, instead of America like previous Macintosh computers. Still, the price and stable operating system made it popular in schools, at home and for small business.

results.title: Machines, engines and motors
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Science fact and fun”.
Provides examples of simple machines such as levers, wheel and axle machines, pulleys, wedges and inclined planes. Also gives definitions of machines, motors, engines and energy. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: Machines to move the mail
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and Harvey Harrison
results.brief_description: The ideas of London’s Dollis Hill Research Station and of the Post Office of the future. Shows examples of automation in the post office such as “Alf” the automatic letter facer, and “Elsie” electronic letter sorting and indicating equipment, to illustrate the future of a completely mechanised postal service.
